subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding a Basis
contentHtml: A basis of a vector space is a set of vectors that span the entire space and are linearly independent.

problem.statementHtml: Find a basis for the vector space spanned by the vectors \[\mathbf{a} = (1, 2), \mathbf{b} = (3, -1), \mathbf{c} = (-1, 0)\].
hints: Hint: Check if any of the given vectors are linearly independent
problem.solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we first check which vectors are linearly independent. We can do this by calculating their determinants:

  • \[\det(\mathbf{a}) = 1 \cdot 2 - 2 \cdot 1 = 0\]
  • \[\det(\mathbf{b}) = 3 \cdot (-1) + (-1) \cdot 1 = -4 eq 0\]

Since \mathbf{b} is linearly independent, we can choose it as one of our basis vectors. We then check which other vectors are linearly independent with \mathbf{b}:

  • \[\det(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}) = 1 \cdot (-1) + 2 \cdot 3 - 2 \cdot (-1) = 7 eq 0\]

We can choose \mathbf{a} as our second basis vector. Finally, we check which other vectors are linearly independent with both \mathbf{b} and \mathbf{a}:

  • \[\det(\mathbf{c}, \mathbf{b}) = (-1) \cdot (-1) + 0 \cdot 3 - 0 \cdot (-1) = 1 eq 0\]

We can choose \mathbf{c} as our third basis vector. Therefore, the basis is \[\mathbf{B} = \left\{ \mathbf{b}, \mathbf{a}, \mathbf{c} ight\}\].

In linear algebra, a basis is a set of vectors that span a vector space.

problem.statementHtml: Find a basis for the vector space spanned by vectors \mathbf{v}_1, \mathbf{v}_2, and \mathbf{v}_3.
problem.solutionHtml:
We can find a basis by writing each vector as a combination of the standard basis vectors.

  • Step 1: Write \mathbf{v}_1 in terms of the standard basis:
  • Math: \[\mathbf{v}_1 = a_{11} \mathbf{i} + a_{12} \mathbf{j} + a_{13} \mathbf{k}\]
  • Description: We're expressing \mathbf{v}_1 as a combination of the standard basis vectors.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Bases and Dimension
contentHtml:
In linear algebra, a basis is a set of vectors that spans the vector space.

  • A basis must be linearly independent, meaning one vector cannot be expressed as a combination of the others.
  • A basis must also span the entire vector space, meaning any vector in the space can be written as a linear combination of the basis vectors.
